attributes.title: Physical Stock Count Variances
attributes.description:
A physical stock count was conducted on February 11, 2025, to verify the accuracy of inventory records and identify potential discrepancies due to misposting, damage, or fraud. The audit compared physical stock levels with system records and observed minor variances in several items, including:

  • Bread stock: -8.50 pieces
  • Packing materials: +122 pieces
  • Wheat bran: +6.75 kg
  • White flour: -0.2 kg
  • Yeast: -0.37 sachets
  • Brown flour: +0.04 kg

While the overall variances were minimal, continuous monitoring is necessary to prevent discrepancies from escalating over time. The results are illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: • We recommend the branch management investigate the root cause of the variances and put more inventory controls to reduces instances of shortages.
attributes.effect: Stock Variances were minimal which indicated that stock controls were effective, however there was need to further strengthen controls to minimize this as it could become significant over time.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Conduct an immediate reconciliation of physical stock against system records.
  • Adjust stock records to reflect actual inventory by the invoicing department
  • Establish a stock variance threshold policy to define acceptable limits

value:
·       The variance observed in the bread stock and other items is minimal. The controls in place are effective, and we will continue to maintain them.

·      Regarding Utto, since we are using older tins that have been in use for a while, we adjust the application of Utto from the standard kgs to ensure the bread quality is not compromised, which explains the observed variance.

·       In prior audit dated 16th Dec 2024:

ü  Bread stock had minimal variation of + 0.5 pieces,

ü  Poly bags had a variance of +28 pieces,

ü  Wheat bran variance of +8.61kg,

ü  Brown Flour had a +4kg,

ü  White flour had a variance of -13.69kgs,

ü  Other items had minimal variation,

ü  Crates had nil balance.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Weight Compliance
attributes.description:
A weight check revealed that several bread varieties were underweight, falling below the KEBS standards as shown below;

  • 400g Long: 89% of sampled loaves were underweight.
  • 1.5kg Loaf: 33% were underweight.

Non-compliance exposes the company to potential legal and regulatory penalties. The table below summarizes the findings:
attributes.recommendation:
·       We also recommend the branch to follow correct productions procedures to avoid overcooling of bread which will result in underweights bread.

·       Certain brands, such as Miniloaf, 400 Long, and all Barrels, should be closely monitored to avoid them being overlooked during packing, as this could lead to underweights.
attributes.effect:
·       Failing to comply with weights and measures laws exposes the company to legal penalties, fines, or sanctions from regulatory authorities.

·       Persistent non-compliance could lead to license suspension or revocation, disrupting operations.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Root Cause Identification of  weight loss such as machines breakdowns, packers pace and addressing Key Issues.
  • Monitoring strict adherence to production guidelines.
  • Regular checks and reviews on bread packed and bread before being distributed to market.

value:
·       Miniloaf orders were low, so it was baked to be sold the following day. We will address overcooling by adjusting production to meet market demand.

·       The dough weight was correct, but instances of oven breakdown caused over baking, resulting in water loss thus contributing to underweight breads.

·       Slow packers contributed to overcooling and we are addressing this with a disciplinary process to improve performance.

·       Regular spot checks on dough weight will be implemented to ensure accuracy.

We will enhance supervision to ensure quality control.

·       We will ensure strict follow up of production process guidelines for weight compliance.

·       Machines breakdown will be reported on time to avoid prolonged baking time.

·       Also Stern disciplinary will be taken to whoever fails to stick to weights standard.

·       Regular spot checks on packed bread will be implemented to ensure no underweight is send to market.

·       In a prior audit report, under weights were mostly observed as follows,

ü  400g-16%

ü  600g-5%

ü  800g-4%

ü  1.5kg-4%
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    We analysed and assessed the fuel consumption rates of Generator for the period 1st January 2025 to 13th February 2025 to determine whether the generators were operating efficiently and within expected parameters. 
•    Based on the data obtained, was considered reasonable and aligned with the operational standards for this period.
•    The fuel consumption between  System Generator records and managers book had a variance of 3Litres as seen below:

·       However the audit noted of the following variation between records and the system as shown below;
attributes.recommendation:
•    The generators should be thoroughly inspected to ensure they are always in good working condition.

·       We also recommend the branch to ensure fueling done should not exceed the gauge to avoid discrepancies between system and manager’s book.
attributes.effect: The generator fuel consumption data shows that the consumption rate is generally aligned with operational standards. However, there is a minor discrepancy (3 liters) between the manager's book and the system's recorded consumption. While this variation is relatively small, it suggests that there may be occasional inconsistencies in fuel tracking or measurement, which could lead to future inaccuracies if not addressed.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Ensure the tracking team’s fueling instructions are consistently followed.
  • Investigate and reconcile any variances between the physical fuel records (manager’s book) and system records
  • Ensure that the generators are thoroughly inspected regularly to confirm they are in good working condition.

value: •    We fuel generator as per instructions from tracking team and the noted variances therefore will be addressed.
Current
Transport/Fleet Department

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       The branch's utilization of human resources in the packaging section was evaluated by assessing packing efficiency, focusing on the number of crates packed per worker compared to the branch's standard efficiency rate of 97 crates per worker.

Ø  For the period 1January- 31January 2025, the average packing efficiency was 84.27 crates per Packer which was below the standard rate of 97 crates per packer for the days sampled as shown in the table below.

Implications

Underutilization of the hired workforce noted was leading to unnecessary costs without significantly improving productivity.
attributes.recommendation:
·       A thorough review and maintenance schedule for packing machines to minimize downtime and ensure consistent performance is recommended.

·       Packers should be closely supervised to ensure they meet the targets. If targets are not met deliberately, the reasons for the shortfall should be identified and presented to management for consideration.
attributes.effect: Underutilization of the hired workforce noted was leading to unnecessary costs without significantly improving productivity.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Address any underperformance by investigating the cause and taking corrective actions.
  • Implement disciplinary measures for packers who do not meet targets. Reassign underperforming staff to other areas if necessary.
  • Implement a review and maintenance plan for packing machines to reduce downtime and ensure consistent performance.

value:
·       The packers are not working fast enough, so we have had to add an extra packer for support.

·       While some new employees show potential for improvement, others may not be able to meet the required pace.

·       We will implement disciplinary actions and make departmental adjustments, moving those who are unable to improve to other areas of production in an effort to meet target goals.

·       Machine-related issues also contributed to inefficiencies, though they were noted in only a few cases during the period.

·       We had cases of absenteeism which has led management to start hiring new employees.

·       Machines related issues also contribute in affecting the targets, we will follow up to ensure we archive the required targets.
·       From prior audit dated 16th December 2024 It was noted that;Average packing efficiency was 83.15 crates per packer.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Vehicles’ fuel consumption analysis
attributes.description:
·       A review was carried out on the mileage records for all route vehicles at the branch for the period from 1 January to 31 January 2024. The objective of this review was to assess whether the fuel consumption of the vehicles was aligned with the established standard rates, thereby ensuring the efficient utilization of resources.

·       We noted that the overall fuel consumption for the fleet aligns closely with the established standard rates except for fleet with variances and which fuel will be recovered as shown below:

Implication

·       The fuel consumption of most routes is in line with the established standard rates, with only minor variances observed.
attributes.recommendation: We recommend conducting a thorough investigation into the Tinganga route to address its slightly higher-than-average fuel consumption.
attributes.effect: The fuel consumption of most routes was in line with the established standard rates, with only minor variances observed.

value: ·      For this routes, Mwingi(KDA 908K) and Kangari (KDB 349Z),we will have fuel recovery while others will be maintained as it is.
·      This will be addressed strictly and action will be taken including recovery.
In prior audit, it was noted that the actual fuel consumption for each vehicle was within the set standard with Tuktuk KTWC 668S being under mechanical repair.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Debtors’ analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debtors' balances as at October 13 February 2025, was conducted to identify any instances of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       We noted that most routes had zero balances and prepaid balances while other routes had balances as illustrated below;

Most clients were supplied with bread the reason being they had sufficient security deposits and or extra cents. This was an attempt to increase sales while also minimizing credit risks
attributes.recommendation: We recommend the marketing team to promptly follow up with the listed institutions to ensure balances are cleared to reduce the instances of Defaults/bad debts.
attributes.effect: Unpaid balances route -wise increases the risk of bad debts, this therefore will affect the company budgets as it will need to allocate larger portions for bad debts provisioning which will reduce the capital to be reinvested in the business.

value: The unpaid debts are being followed up by branch sales rep [Nzomo] to be cleared
Sales team are following all pending debts.
Sales Department

attributes.title: Mini shop Spot Check.
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted at the Mini Shop on February 13, 2025, to verify that all bread loaded for sale was properly accounted for and to ensure that the recorded sales was aligned with the balances associated with the provided pay bill number, given that the Mini Shop operates under a policy of not accepting physical cash.

·       We observed that all sales recorded up to the time of the spot check were properly accounted for. Additionally, the physical stock of bread, including all loadings and top-ups, excluding sales, was available as expected, as outlined below:
attributes.recommendation: We recommend the branch management to regularly conduct periodic reviews for Mini shop to ensure that controls remain effective.
attributes.effect: Mini Shop's controls were functioning effectively, however the branch should maintain a record for the transaction charges.

value: The controls in place are effective and thus we shall maintain.
In previous audit report, mini shop bread balance was subtracted from the total loadings to determine the daily sales, which matched the confirmed Mpesa till amount.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       As part of our routine checks, a cash verification was conducted to ensure that the physical cash on hand was consistent with the recorded cash balance in the cash-flow records. The review also aimed to assess the adherence to cash management controls.

·       The spot check revealed that cash balances were well-controlled, with a minimal variance of -1, which was attributed to change balances.

Implication

·       Small variance noted in cash office indicates that the cash controls are strong and working effectively.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The minimal variance -1 suggests that there may be slight discrepancies due to small change fluctuations however, formalizing a variance threshold (e.g., within ±1% of the recorded balance), should be implemented and ensure that any variance exceeding this threshold is investigated.
attributes.effect: Negligible variance noted in cash office indicates that the cash controls are strong and working effectively.

value: The cashier is maintaining proper records and the controls are effective, but we shall follow up to ensure minimal or nil variance balances.
To maintain the same trend
·       From prior audit report, cashier had correctly accounted for all cash, as the cash counted matched the cash flow balance.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       The purpose of this test was to evaluate the mixing chart documents, both shift-wise and summarized, for the period from 01 January to 31 January 2025. The key focus areas were to assess the branch’s Utto oil consumption, average yield, and instances of remixes as illustrated below:

Ø  The Utto consumption was at1 unit per bag implying a ration of bags to utto unit of 1:1

Ø  The average yield for the reviewed period was 191.57 loaves per bag.

Ø  Average production was 93.79 bags per day representing 76.88% of target achievement which is 122 bags as tabled below:

Implication

·       The branch achieved only 76.88% of the daily production target.

·        This shortfall of 23.12% indicates that there may be inefficiencies or constraints affecting the branch's ability to meet its target.Factors such as equipment downtime, market dynamics and labour issues could be contributing to the underperformance.
attributes.recommendation:
·       It is essential for the branch to align production targets with actual sales levels.

·       It is recommended that the branch collaborates more closely with the sales team to ensure alignment between production and actual sales demand.

The branch should provide the sales team with accurate production forecasts and product availability, while the sales team should focus on driving sales, exploring new markets and implementing promotional strategies to increase demand
attributes.effect: The branch achieved only 76.88% of the daily production target. This shortfall of 23.12% indicates that there may be inefficiencies or constraints affecting the branch's ability to meet its target. Factors such as equipment downtime, market dynamics and labour issues could be contributing to the underperformance.

value:
·       Due to low sales, we have reduced production to minimize wastage.

While this control is necessary to prevent losses, we will ensure that production targets are strictly met once demand increases.

·       This was due low sales we plan our production based on our demand.

Sales team are working hard to ensure they meet our production and sales capacity of the branch.

·       Previous audit report dated 16.12.2024 indicated the following:

ü  Yield-191.62,

ü  Utto-1:1~ 100%,

ü  Average Prod. - 102.81.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Damages Check
attributes.description:
·       We conducted an evaluation of bread damages at the Thika branch from January 1 to January 31, 2025, to assess whether the production process adhered to established quality control measures. The review aimed to ensure compliance with the predefined damage thresholds of 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.

·       The review revealed that market damages accounted for 0.91% of total sales, which exceeded the allowed limit of 0.50%. Productions damages, on the other hand, were at 0.30% of total production which was above the maximum acceptable limit as detailed below:

Production Damages analysis

Market Damages analysis

Findings

The issue of old and potentially damaged tins identified in the previous audit continues to cause production damages and is now affecting the quality of bread as seen in increased returns.
attributes.recommendation:
·       We recommend the branch to strengthen damages controls to ensure that production and market damages remain within the acceptable thresholds of 0.2% and 0.5% respectively.

·       We also recommend an immediate action which is needed to replace or repair the damaged tins to prevent further impact on product quality.

·       The branch should work closely with supermarkets to ensure that bread orders are in line with actual sales potential.

·       Additionally, a more stringent return policy should be implemented, potentially involving shared costs or limiting the quantity of bread orders, to minimize returns due to over ordering.
attributes.effect:
Both market and production-related damages are leading to financial losses, with the total cost implication amounting to approximately 149,135.88 (combining the production and market-related damages).

The production damages are closely linked to the quality of the materials used (e.g., damaged tins). There is a need to ensure that the production process adheres strictly to quality standards, especially regarding packaging materials. If left unaddressed, this issue could cause further deterioration in product quality and increase the number of returns, affecting customer satisfaction and long-term brand loyalty.

Exceeding the allowed thresholds for both production and market-related damages might expose the company to risks of non-compliance with internal policies

value:
·       We have worn-out tins, particularly the 400g ones. The operations team is aware of this issue, and communication has been made to ensure their replacement.

·       An oven breakdown occurred during the period, which was resolved on time but the damage had already affected production.

·       The condition of the tins has contributed to low-quality baked bread, affecting both quality and appearance, leading to customer rejections.

Supermarkets may be experiencing low sales and poor planning, resulting in large orders that cannot be sold and are subsequently returned to the branch.

·       The issue was caused by most tins being worn out and damaged.

·       Oven damage also contributed to the problem.

The need to replace the tins has been raised with management.

·       In a prior audit report dated 16th Dec 2024 ;

ü  Production damages rate was 0.21 % of total production,

ü  Market damages rate stood at 0.54% of total sales inclusive of supermarket returns.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the production efficiency was evaluated to determine if workers were meeting their set production targets and to identify areas for improvement based on the current workforce utilization, actual production versus expected production and cost implications of inefficiencies.

·       We noted that production efficiency per production worker was at 4.37 bags, which meets the expected set standard of 4.3 bags per production worker.

·       A summary of the audit findings is illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation:
·       While the current workforce is meeting the target, hiring should be regularly reviewed to ensure that it aligns with production goals.

To prevent machine breakdowns from affecting production efficiency, it is crucial to invest in regular machine maintenance and timely upgrades.
attributes.effect:
·       The production workers met the expected standard of 4.3 bags per worker, with an actual efficiency of 4.37 bags per worker. This shows that workers are meeting the set expectations, which is a positive indicator of productivity and workforce management.

While workers are performing well, machine breakdowns have been noted as a factor that can affect overall efficiency. Even though the workforce is performing adequately, any machinery issues can slow down the production process and impact overall output.

value:
·       The commitment of the hired workers, whose work rate was higher, contributed to them meeting the standard rate of 4.3 bags.

The controls in place will be maintained.

We will hire workers as per standard operating efficiency.

Machines breakdown sometimes affects the efficiency.
·       In prior audit dated 16th December 2024, it was noted that, average production efficiency was 4.35 bags per production worker.
Operations/Production Department
